pFi5qDYsi6fMO4TwtICFsg.text: Great place for drinks!  The tequila selection was quite good and the bartender was friendly and efficient :) we only ate ceviche which was delicious!

1h8VZITSBlpfp-WtV_j0aQ.text: Great cocktails and quite decent food. Good alternative to other Mexican restaurants in the area. A bit on the pricey side especially for cocktails...

--QguPSNdZKsy5KxRJICSQ.text: Complements its fake-mex albeit fresh cuisine with a pleasant environment and staff. Too pricey given its poor rendition of Mexican dishes.

TiymOy6yNBMZG5PXAksbEg.text: Went for the preview opening and had a great lunch at Cantina Laredo. Pleasant, attentive staff - particularly Abigail (our Section Manager) and Natalie (our waitress). They brought round after round of fresh tortilla chips, guacamole and salsa whilst we were waiting for our meals - we had to stop them bring more out as we would not have been able to eat our food! :-) Mother chose chicken fajita soft tacos which were excellent. Our steaks with a chipotle sauce and Bacon wrapped Tiger prawns with Monterry Jack cheese was too much seasoned with salt, coupled with the salt from the sauce and bacon. I would recommend that if you have a low salt tolerance like us, or are on a low sodium diet then just let the staff know. The toilets were well designed and in black slate tiling. Great place for crashing out for lunch if around Covent Garden / St Martin's Lane. Good family restaurant. Overall, had a great lunch and we will definitely be going back.

0P8MmcfOJ2UjDzHJhu_iFg.text: Came here on a Tuesday evening and it was pretty quiet. However it was very clean, the service was excellent and the food very good. They mix guacamole at the table which is easily as good as you would make at home if you like that kind of thing. I had an enchilada which was delicious and they didn't stint on the tequila in the margarita which made me VERY happy! it's not particularly expensive either. have recommended to others since and i will definitely be back.

dytNW9-hBQrPkwtfAF7Vsg.text: Ask for Guacamole, youll see what happens :). This place is just great, staff is very very very nice and the food is more than good. Spicy enough and love the fact I can make my own Fajitas. Also love the fact this is one of those not super cheap places (but worth it!!) that you actually finish and you are FULL - no tiny dishes. Great experience.

ZrqnYH3SINtGKQnlgGluig.text: i had no idea it was a US chain till after i ate there,we just went for pudding, so i really cant comment on the rest of it. it we got the chocolate cake thing and a apple pie. both of which were absolutely saturated in  sugar syrup. they had it come in on a sizzling platter, so it looked really cook at first, but was so sweet in the end we couldnt finish them. annoying.

uCODWLMSsS_vdcG7n_KEkg.text: Less of a review, more of a warning: this restaurant is one to avoid at all costs! The food is an absolute disaster. If i'd paid £1.99 for a ready meal and it tasted like this I would feel ripped off although if you go in with the idea that a ready meal is the standard to expect you might not feel so ripped off. Particularly laughable is their use of the word 'Gourmet', unless they think that Gourmet simply means 'expensive'? This is not authentic Mexican food. This is Mexican food tweaked to appeal to the USA (you'll notice most good reviews around the web are from US travelers finding a taste of home). Fair is fair though and not everything here is abysmal - the service is very good, helpful and friendly  shame it's not enough to make up for all the other faults.

ENNgnSmxK6Oq3q7Y2mcxpw.text: Mexican food in London?!Right after we order, they bring out two kinds of salsa. The warm tomatillo salsa has to be the best salsa I've ever had! It's got a lil spice to it, but not too much. We also ordered the guacamole appetizer which they made fresh right in front of our table. The guac was a little plain, it needed some garlic and more lime juice in my opinion. So I mixed in the tomatillo salsa with the guac and it was PERFECT! I could eat that for every meal of the day for about 8 days before getting sick of it. (Prop bet me, I dare you!)Main course: I couldn't decide between the chile relleno or the enchiladas, so I got the enchiladas de chile relleno. Bad choice, it sounded like a great idea at the time and looked like it would have tons of flavor, but it failed.Dessert: Mexican Brownie!!!! WOW! Don't you dare even think about not getting dessert or getting something else! It's a chocolate brownie with pecans served on a hot skillet with mexican brandy butter poured onto the plate and Vanilla (sometimes cinnamon) ice cream on top. The smell that comes off the dish is one of the most delectable scents that will grace your nose in your entire life! Like, if I bottled it up and sprayed it on Pee-wee Herman, he would be intensely irresistible to you, that mouthwatering!Even though I didn't like my main course, the salsa and brownie were so damn delicious that I have to go back.anitaeat.com

iX2OWODsAb2dbiS3mt8AJw.text: It's hard to find Mexican food at anything other than the fast food end of the market, so Cantina Laredo was a great find. We went there on a Saturday evening and the atmosphere was buzzing. Happily, the interior is spacious enough that you can still enjoy your private conversation without raising your voice. The best of both worlds really.We ordered the guacamole for starters, which they mixed at the table. It was outstandingly good. The tacos and enchiladas for our main were also excellent  stuffed full of fresh ingredients and flavour. The staff are so friendly and helpful. A great place for a group of friends to celebrate a special occasion or for an intimate dinner for two with none of the stuffiness that usually comes with restaurants that are hyped as 'romantic'. I'd advise you book ahead. They have a lot of tables, but the place was almost full when we got there at 6pm. Hope to return again in the future.

nlLB2R7d6uH963J98_BtKA.text: It sort of annoyed me when the waiter came to take my order and said that this is an authentic Texas chain from the US. Don't be fooled, no one who is actually from California/Texas (the hub of mexican/"tex mex" food that this place is trying to emulate) would actually ever eat here. They do have it in the US, but its average at best. The one really good part is the free table salsas/chips -- the chips come hot sometimes and the salsas are homemade and delicious. However the entrees always leave something to be desired. The meat is not particularly tasty or fresh and the cheese is processed. If you order guacamole, be prepared for a gimmick where they make it fresh at your table and then charge you like £10 for the pleasure (not worth it). On top of that, the margaritas they sell are very pricy as well. I have been twice, and I never leave feeling like I get good value-for-money. I realise that this is London and you can't expect much on the Mexican front, but there are better places. And frankly, I would rather eat at Chipotle up the road and pay £7 versus blowing a £20 at this place. It's also telling that they are always more on the emptier side versus the other covent garden restaurants in the immediate vicinity.

4lQ-D9xmjdEC2o-FlxWxBw.text: I came across this restaurant on a Friday night. Excellent customer service, great atmosphere. The margarita was huge and its taste delightful. Let's not talk about the main meal...to die for...I would have licked the plate if I could. Dessert was sizzling at the table and absolutely very tasty. I will definitely go back again and I highly recommend it.

NIymdEuSj3h1mVToZT928g.text: The best mexican restaurant in london... not quite on a par with what you could get in la or dallas but a real step up for london! friendly, attentive staff. good, varied menu. value for money and good portions. Must try the mexican brownie dessert yum !!

VNe6m-8j1VeqVqX7tuTtwA.text: I lived in Dallas, Texas for 11 years and ate at the Cantina Laredo at Preston and Royal dozens of time. One of the best tex-mex places in Dallas. I've equally enjoyed the location at the DFW airport and in Columbus Ohio. This London location is on par with the rest of the small chain. I doubt there is better in London. Enjoy the margaritas, tamales, tacos al carbpn, mole!

eXPFv4Yuo_V3T_uyiTkakQ.text: The guacamole prepared at the table is a bit of theatre but the result tasted fresh and was possibly the best I'd tasted before. I had a vegetable fajita which include a large assortment of vegetable which were all excellent together. Service was attentive but not too in the face and while not cheap was great value for money and a pretty smart place to eat in central London.

iT29QdendnQAPbLPjn1yFg.text: It's Mexican food in London that actually tastes like...Mexican food. It's not Cajun food or god knows what else, it's actually...Mexican food. Halleluljah!I enjoyed a lunch of a good glass of wine and some good fresh Mexican food here, and would recommend it. The portions are pretty healthy, and I certainly didn't worry about going hungry, especially with the (gasp!) free chips and salsa provided. (Free chips and salsa are standard in Texas, but in London!? Dude!)

V0FSxzb8C_2zKNbIvm210A.text: Table Side Guac made right in front of you.Unlimited ChipsFantastic SalsaDelicious Tapas Amazing FoodGreat ServiceWonderful margaritasCorona and other bottled BeerGood amount of food to keep you satisfied all dayTable Side GuacamoleTable Side Guacamole that has everything you desire in it.Need I say again... Table Side Guac :]]To sum this up. Cantina Laredo is Amazingly Delicious.

euGw_-D9pHY7BbZvBiG-fw.text: Cantina Laredo promises gourmet Mexican food. I presume they mean gourmet as in Gourmet Burger Kitchen as it really isn't anything special. There is nothing on the menu that you won't  find at any chain Mexican restaurant and presentation is no better.The big "feature" dish is their guacamole, prepared table side. I have nothing against dishes prepared table side, as long as it adds something to the dish. All we got was a waitress mashing some avocado quietly at the end of the table and then adding some pre-chopped ingredients. The fact is, this was some of the blandest guacamole I've  ever tasted. You can't help but wonder that if it was prepared in a kitchen by a chef they might have seasoned it correctly. At £6.95 for a bowl of dip it's pretty inexcusable.The main courses don't get any better. I went for one of their house specialities, the Enchiladas Veracruz. On first impression, this didn't look too bad but it was by far the most inedible thing I've been served in any restaurant. The chicken was so dry that it felt like cotton wool in my mouth. You could have chewed on it forever and not been able to swallow it as it sucked the moisture from your mouth. Had I not been there as part of someone's birthday meal I would definitely have sent the dish back. As it was I ended up having to scrape all the chicken out and eat around it. This made it pretty evident that there wasn't much flavour going on elsewhere.Finally we arranged to bring a birthday cake for desert. They agreed to bring it to the table but not much else. We were offered a bent steak knife to cut it due to health and safety according to the waitress. (We later joined a party at another restaurant where they had been given a massive totally undangerous pallet knife for their cake). We had to ask  for plates and got no cutlery. The waiting staff were pretty uninterested and slow.All in all this is a very expensive way to discover the worst imaginable food. There are so many cheaper better Mexican places in London that you would be mad to go here.

q9Z3vVlW_ezczkYpusk_lw.text: This place serves very good Mexican/Tex-Mex food.  However, it is quite expensive so it would be hard to be a regular here.  I'm a native Texan who is fanatical about Tex-Mex.  When I am outside of Texas in the U.S., I often love to seek out a location of Cantina Laredo for Mexican food that even Texans are happy to eat.  The Cantina Laredo location here is a very, very close replica of locations that I have been to in Dallas and Nashville.  Some things are different: for instance, I would love to see cheese enchiladas on the menu and I'd like to see the default sides with entrees be rice and beans instead of rice and vegetables.  But, this location does a very nice job nonetheless.  Two of us split a Fiesta Platter: which was a plate of sizzling meats (beef, chicken, prawns, lamb) served with tortillas, a small amount of guacamole, sour cream, pico de gallo, and cheese.  It was very good and the tortillas were surprisingly fairly good as well (the quality of tortillas is often decisive in my view.)  The chips and salsa were also good.  The first batch is free, which is nice.  An additional salsa was an additional pound but overall still a good deal. The service was also fantastic, which from other reviews, looks like it has been a trend.

qHzTOYeZX9WhMrTpUEd8lQ.text: American in London:This is probably one of the best Tex-Mex options in London.  The margaritas are great and the food options have never been disappointing.They have there own Vegetarian menu, which I think is amazing.  I get the Avocado Enchiladas whenever I can.The area is spacious for London standards and the staff is friendly.

SuREtPJQrY4s7RUztWQ6JA.text: Well, I love the food here, and I'm notoriously difficult to please when it comes to Mexican food, because I cook it myself and know how it should taste.I am from California originally, so have missed real Mexi-food on this side of the Atlantic which has lead me to some true disasters, yes, I'm talking about Cafe Pacifico and La Perla, which bear about as much resemblance to true Mexican cuisine as a weiner schnitzel in a Thai joint.If I had done this review after we first ate there this past July, it would have been five stars, because that day all the planets aligned, it was sunny and warm on the outdoor patio, the waiter was attentive and entertaining, and the food was the best Mexican I've ever eaten on ANY side of the ocean, including our local Mexican joint in Santa Monica, Gilbert's El Indio. The food was really well-prepared and to the right recipe Mexican flavours. But then the restaurant had only just opened and the head honcho from Arizona was in the place making sure everything was done right. I said on that day it was the best Mexican restaurant I had eaten in anywhere, including Mexico itself, San Francisco, all up and down the west coast of the USA including Portland and Seattle and Los Angeles.When we ate there two nights ago after an absence of 3 months, the standards had lowered. Maybe it's just me, but I got the distinct impression that the chef in the kitchen was not the same one, and was no longer a true Mexican cook, as I know they did have in the summertime.The table-made guacamole was good, the chips were warm and never-ending and free, the salsas are delicious and I especially appreciate the touch of having the green tomatillo salsa warm in temperature as well as spicy. BUT! I ordered the enchilada espinaca, a spinach and onion-filled corn tortilla with very bland and insipid cream sauce on it, which was a mistake. The spinach was gritty and full of sand and I couldn't eat it and sent it back.This won't discourage me from going back, they took it off the bill and offered me anything else I wanted, and gave us two free coupons for the guacamole, which was generous of them. In fact one of my tablemates went back three nights in a row for dinner, he liked it so much!Next time I'll get the fajitas, those were terrific last time we went. Stick to what you know, I should have remembered that little pearl of wisdom.

hiFoq_U1fsPtfRm-Jr7qNw.text: I was reluctantly dragged here by a friend who swore it was "good Mexican" food.  One look at the menu convinced me it was Mexican inspired or Mexican-ish or maybe tex-mex which would explain the random pineapple, courgette, creamed spinach, aspargus, potato confit and pumpkin floating around on the menu! I went along but started with the non commital chicken quesadillas .. What's £5.50 in the grand scheme of things? That actually wasn't too bad. I got another order as my main bc I didn't feel like making a £15 mistake on some of their questionable combos (I.e enchiladas del mar or tacos al pastor).Overall my experience with the quesadillas were ok, will I be back to try more? Unlikely

HwFboFDI2Ysk6zvkxs7_pA.text: Absolutely loved everything I ate here today. The guacamole dip, carne asada tacos, chicken flautas and the brownie dessert. Everything was delicious!

_B2mGMsHczHDJI81PjJ-QQ.text: Had no idea this was a chain in the US as they never opened one up in around NY.  It's definitely one of the better Mexican restaurants around London.  The Guacamole is good but wish there was a little more salt and Cilantro/Coriander.  My company was there for our Christmas dinner and it was a pretty good set up and so much food.  The quesadillas were delicious but the tamales were a little strange.  The steak was definitely the way to go as it was cooked and seasoned perfectly.  I had a bit of the pork but it was way too dry and bland.  The chocolate brownie was a little on the dense side but well complimented with the vanilla ice cream.  They serve delicious mojitos and have a decent wine selection.

Daajd0fGTGaYu6kXYOJg2Q.text: Listen compadres, when you miss Mexican food so much that even the previously dreaded parade of clapping sombrero-adorning waiters on birthday brigade marching through a chain restaurant with a slice of flaming flan would be music to your ears, you know that you could take a chunk of lard, a can of beans and a corn chip, call it a burrito, and you'd be happy.If that's the case, than consider me ecstatic. (And out of breath.)The table-side guac show. Warm tortilla chips. Refried beans con queso. Spicy salsa. Ice people, ice. That's all you need to know to go. Go I say!

CFoHk2fc9m60hT0TuvAb0g.text: As a long time Californian, I must admit that my expectations for Mexican Food in England were pretty low ... heck, finding decent Mexican in New York City (Manhattan) can be a challenge!Ate here with a group of about 15 in a private room.  Service was a bit slow in terms of delivery drinks (tasty!), chips and salsa, but I was surprised that it didn't take them long to serve our meals.Delicious!  Everyone agreed!  No complaints, no returns, just a group of happy customers ... many of whom were from the LA and San Diego area ... meccas for Mexican food.While I won't call this authentic Mexican, it was very good.  If you are in town and need something that resembles "the real deal", I'd recommend this place.

DcHK-RTLN-jmDdkH1yUSjw.text: This place is ok.  It is a massive restaurant in Covent Garden in the new chain strip area there, which means large restaurants with very little personality and a mix of tourists and locals.  We started with some margaritas at the bar--they were tasty but REALLY expensive.  I did appreciate them coming around with chips and salsa--tasty salsa although it does come from a jar. I ended up with chicken mole--it was decent.  The cache is the guacamole they make tableside.  A bit gimicky, chainy, and lacking.  Be prepared to shell out the big bucks for the margaritas!

HaPC43w-HPJCxiJ1cZf6VA.text: Not sure whether it was price or lack of atmosphere but I wasn't entirely impressed. If you're starving then pop in for some guacamole - handmade from scratch at your table. But look elsewhere for a sit down meal.

96Eoxqy-dJYG0oKtY_G0EQ.text: Nothing horrible, but there is better Mexican in London. Nearby, I would prefer La Bodega Negra but this is certainly an OK option.

EXgW3GnHXhRtrZAYNiYhGg.text: One word: Margaritas. They are half price on Wednesday night and they have lots of delicious flavors and are the reason this place gets 4 stars and not 3. I went here with my girls last Wednesday and we each got two margaritas, (the limit) and enjoyed a tasty dinner. Located near Leicester Square tube station, Cantina Laredo serves up contemporary Mexican food. We all enjoyed our entrees and I would go back to this restaurant for their flavorful and creative takes on Mexican classics. It's a little on the pricy side and I don't know if their food is totally worth it, but finding good Mexican food in London is hard so I guess beggars can't be choosers!

E5S09sCOQY__xfPbhGQSjQ.text: The food and drink here is great.The custom and service is, to be honest second to none.  I had an unfortunate incident with a mouse/rat trap which left an item of clothing unwearable, but I am taking this up with the management, which Im assuming should be resolved.Anyway, I digress!  The blended margaritas are truly amazing and the food is great, they even have a dedicated vegetarian menu. Heather is an absolute godsend is service, always keen to help, suggest and keep on top.Well done, finally a mexican restaurant in London that excels on all points.The desserts are especially something unique!

JCdtPcBnMQZmaIdc7TzW7w.text: Holly mole, guacamole! Now being a Brit, with limited access to decent Mexican food and authentic experiences, I thought I was having my leg pulled when people mentioned that guacamole was going to be made, right in front of my face! There was no leg pulling going on here, if fact, not even a tug.Cantina Laredo is a lovely place to eat; it's clean, has huge booths that sit more than 6 people, has an extensive menu with some things that I haven't see anywhere else in London. It's a classy Mexican joint all right.I actually get quite excited about going for Mexican food now. I can act a bit like a dick and say "well this is more Californian that Mexican, don't ya know". I hate myself and love myself in that single moment. I feel like I should have given this place 5 stars. It really was fabulous food and right up my street, but the dick in my is not allowing that. I'll come back again though, actually, I might just go ahead and book a table right now.

lV8J7UuEMd3AhgBiyOlWKg.text: I had a meeting here a few weeks ago. Having read mixed reviews, I wasn't expecting much, but actually - it wasn't bad.Sure, it looks a little bit like a chain, but our waitress was very nice and explained the menu with the care you just don't see in other cookie cutter tex-mex restaurants.Anyway. We went for juice and a few mixed starters. Unfortunately my friend didn't like spicy food, so I couldn't really try this place as fully as I'd like. But the tortillas were great and the salsa to die for. It had a real kick.We had a mixture of toastados, tacos and tacquitos - all of which were perfectly adequate.I didn't have any of the more impressive dishes (guacamole made at your table etc.) - but I'm not really in a rush to go back.

h3MJzPhdIBQ3NyMPCIxwEw.text: A friend and I went here for a relatively casual meal on a Saturday night. Cantina Laredo is perfect for just that. They have an extensive menu to begin with. The wait staff are efficient but not overly friendly or pushy. The Mexican drinks were amazing. The salsa made in front of you was excellent. My main wasn't what I expected but it was OK. My friends was gorgeous though so I guess I just made a bad choice. They have a small bar that seemed casual for a drop in or pre/post dinner drinks. I've not been to any other Mexican food spot in London so I'm unable to compare it but I definitely recommend it.

yq4k6gowZCCEiQ0FrEJU6Q.text: Stumbled upon Cantina Laredo in Coventry Garden when Bill's was too crowded.  Glad we did.  The food is excellent.  The desserts are some of the best we have ever had.  The entrees were delicious.  Will de finitely be back.

-iWfLDbXxP8mGXr3Ao7x8Q.text: I live in Dallas and have eaten at several locations of Cantina Laredo countless times.  This location is close to the same experience.  Not having iced tea is a crime.  If you're from Texas and you find a Mexican place from Texas, they should have real iced tea.  You should have pitchers if it ready.  Also the chips are WAY too salty.  Fajitas are perfect and the service was prompt and pleasant in all ways.  Great location.  For any vacationing Texan or wanna be, this is the place to go.

VEcdzbNz-pNfIaHRz4-ROQ.text: This place was very busy on a Saturday night at around 6:30. It kind of had a chain feel to it, but I don't think it is a chain. I could be wrong. When I called to make a resi, I was told they were full but that we could book as priority seating (priority over walk ins) we were given a buzzer when we got there and was told we'd have to wait up to 15 mins. I started to doubt my choice of coming here, but after a really good beer at the bar we were taken down to our table which was around the back in a much nicer setting. I think the front area is for families while the back was more couples and older families. Much more preferable for me. It wasn't full, so the whole priority seating and then the buzzer thing seemed a little weird, but whatever. The food though, I loved it. The guac is made table side and by, in our case, a very hot waitress. It was really nice, filled with tomatoes, onion, peppers and more. That was the highlight for me. I only had chicken fajitas and my date had the veggie ones. She's not a vegetarian, I would not be on a date with her if she was... But after a few days with me in London, I think I'd introduced her to way more meat than she could handle, wink wink. The desserts looked brilliant, they came out on a sizzling platter and then the servers pour some kind of creamy looking butter over the top. They looked great, but we declined this time. Overall a good experience, I would and have recommended it to others. Cheers.

Y8dUxYhPQ1EK9V0ogEsm5A.text: I might have been mentioning it a few times already, but I do miss Mexican Cuisine! One day my colleagues were very excited to announce the arrival of a new Mexican restaurant in the city centre...and we immediately decided to give it a try...non sooner said than done are we heading to Covent Garden to judge the authenticity of the food at Cantina Laredo. And here's my verdict: It was ok...it wasn't bad , but it didn't knock off my socks either.From the food-point -of-view: the portions were very generous and the taste was quite alright. I especially enjoyed the warm tortilla chips and the different kinds of accompanying warm salsas. I also liked, that our waitress was making the guacamole right in front of us...which was fun to watch and very entertaining - however, it didn't taste so great as the spice-mixture must've contained too much white pepper.From the atmosphere-pont-of-view: immediately when we entered the restaurant I felt transported into an American suburb where this establishment would have fit in perfectly. In fact, the seating arrangements were so generous that it would have fit perfectly that never-walking and SUV-driving-clientele. (Ups, this might be a little harsh.) The waiting staff was equally inspired by the American service industry: attentive but yet somewhat dull and not very caring beyond what is absolutely necessary. What do I mean by that? - Well, I like it when people are kind to me, but I don't want them to be kind only because some kind of service-standard prescribes it - otherwise I feel like I'm handled like the chicken that we've been eating...So, will I come back? Only if my Mexican craving cannot be satisfied otherwise...

j9nsEGksZO3pM8KVFAtVUg.text: Okay so full disclosure, I am a pretty big snob when it comes to Mexican food. I lived in Southern California for a while and maintain that greasy, cheese-covered, no-English-spoken, hole-in-the-wall Mexican restaurants will always taste so much better than TexMex or "fancy" Mexican. After living in DC for five years I resigned myself to the fact that the East Coast of the US has no good authentic Mexican food, so high-end TexMex will have to do. So far I'm feeling that London will be on a similar page.Cantina Laredo has what you'd expect from any other relatively expensive global Mexican chain. The food is tasty, ingredients are fresh, the service is impeccable, and the price tags are hefty. The guacamole is made to order at the table, which is always a plus because I can make sure they leave out the cilantro (coriander for the Brits). We ordered the mixed fajitas, which included a surprisingly small portion of steak and chicken, supplemented with a ton of grilled onions. The mojitos were very tasty, and my colleague loved his Michelada. A pleasant meal overall, but not mind-blowing.

2iS7Av0nGQc_562Lst8Saw.text: Don't bother unless you want to pay over the odds for distinctly average food and poor service.It was a busy Saturday night but not too busy. We had a pre-booked table for 8 people and were seated promptly.Service was brusque, she took our drinks order and then came back to take our starters order. Starters arrived and were eaten (small portions of average food), we sat with the empty plates for a good ten minutes before they were cleared and then a while later our main orders were taken. Odd!I had a shared mixed fajita dish for two to share as it was one of their signature dishes. The mixed meats were ok but nothing special, they were stingy on the guacamole and there were no jalapeños!! Upon request a plate of them were brought out for the table to share but they were tasteless, not even a kick to them.I had the churros for pudding and the chocolate dipping sauce didn't taste of anything. Oh, it was so disappointing.A 12.5% service charge was whacked on top of our bill - uh-uh, I don't think so!!The thing that baffles me most is that although this is a big restaurant and we were sat far enough away from the kitchen we still came out with our clothes and hair smelling of food. Yuck!Tourist-trap alert!! Eat elsewhere or be dwindled!

yxxXEvQdqrPykqrK4wuviQ.text: Good Mexican food. Great quick service without feeling rushed. Reasonably priced for Central London. Worth booking ahead at weekends as there were a ton of people waiting to be seated both before and after we ate.Overall all a cracking night. Would definitely go again.

rR17zA_n-5esPin6JAjz3g.text: I like this place but in no way did it blow me away.We have some cocktails which were fine and ordered the fiesta grill to share - this in itself was devent - looked good, smelled good....tasted.....ok!The qauil was cooked into oblivion, it may as well have been chicken or any other poultry.The churros...nice but as others have said the choclate dipping sauce lacked a taste of chocolate!Good for a prethreatre snack but dont put up with the inforced 12.5% tip - it is illegal and I was happy to point this out to the manager!!

xnDPjsWhdY5v2qMfk_Sf8g.text: Guacamole made fresh at your table, sign me up! Yup, in a land where Indian food and curries seems to reign supreme I found a Spanish gem. Cantina Laredo is a great place to meet people for dinner, have an intimate-ish meal or even a nice lunch. Yes, I've done all of the above and plan to again.The service is good, attentive and friendly. The quality of the food is great and at a decent value as well. I'm totally a fan of this place and took some visiting friends last time around. We all left quite happy. Listen up amigos this is a place to put on your list especially if you're looking for some Spanish flare. It's muy bueno y'all... that's all!

gLCLDZyHEh3aaZ5chLcMVA.text: We took my friend's dad here who was visiting London- and he absolutely loved it (as did we!). Everything tastes fresh and authentic and the menu had some dishes to choose from which I have not come across in Mexican dining before. I had the Del Mar Enchiladas which was fantastic. Would highly recommend to all seafood lovers out there. The spicy chili/cream sauce really topped it off (no pun intended). My fellow diners were vegetarian and were more than happy with the selection of food on offer. All round very pleased! Service was amazing and ambiance great- but then again you get what you pay for as this place is not cheap- but well worth it :)

X_DBmi_j9xbf3squMyZEaA.text: If I could cut this review in half I'd give the place 4 stars for drinks/snacks, and 1 star for the food.  Granted, I only ate the food here on my first visit, but it was bad enough that I know it wasn't simply an off day -- the ingredients, recipes and cooking techniques are not those which should be used when making mexican food (or any food, really).I come for the margaritas, the big banquettes, and the chips & salsa (which used to be free and unlimited -- ouch).  The frozen margaritas are strong and delicious, and the slightly depressing American-chain ambiance is the perfect place to get loud and obnoxiously drunk, reminding other diners that they should've ventured elsewhere if they wanted to eat (if the food itself doesn't clue them in).Waitresses were refreshingly American and/or antipodean so shit went down without a hitch. Go for the margaritas, stay for the chips, leave for dinner!

rvxslI4EhaLCjOgIjAmlTA.text: Everything about my experience at Cantina Laredo was FAB!!!!I contacted Ryan, one of the owners of the family establishment and he made a quick and efficient booking for my group.On arrival, we I was greeted by his father - I said it's a family place - and he was so warm and welcoming and we chatted about his upcoming trip to NYC. Charming man.I propped up the bar for a margarita - don't leave here until you have one of these - and waited for my friends to arrive.Shown to our table and treated to the freshest and most delicious guacamole I've had in a looooong time. Make right at your table...oh, yes, I ordered another margarita too.The food was delicious and beautifully presented. I'm a Mexiholic so I was looking for vibrant colours and flavours that popped and they didn't disappoint. Ryan, the son, appeared to checked on us and thanked us for coming.Everyone who works for and with Cantina Laredo was professional, friendly and attentive.For the Americans in London, get yourself down there for your Mex-Fix!!

TLqS7jVuBMtDkMI0MEFLBg.text: Ok folks, first of all I am Texan and being from Texas you STARVE for anything close to Mexican Food. They have one of these in Houston so we wanted to try it. Being picky on Mexican food as I am, this is pretty darn close to home. The queso is not tex mex but more Mexican as my friends mom use to make. It is good and the salsa and guacamole is good. They have fresh jalapeños and habenaro if you ask. Refried beans are spot on. My wife liked the rice and fajitas were good. Not as good as lupe tortilla in Houston but GOOD. It is a train ride for us but worth it. I am coming back!

KFJxqTc3EO7pdfJar6vpgg.text: I am a big fan of Cantina Laredo. As a global chain restaurant, they do a great job, and I have eaten at their locations around the world. My rating, however, is based on the attitude of their staff on the night of January 22, 2015. While their Google information says that the restaurant is open until 11:30 pm, their web site has an asterisk that indicates they actually close 1.5 hours earlier than the posted time: 10:00 pm. I showed up at 10:01 pm, after a West End show.When I asked to be seated, I was told that the kitchen was already closed. When I pointed out that it was one-minute past 10:00, the hostess asked "Can you read? The sign on the door says 10:00. It is 10:01." Then giggled with the other hostess about my inability to read. I was shocked at this response, and said that with an attitude like hers, I would not be coming back to Cantina Laredo. Her response was, "Ok. That's fine." Then they giggled together again.As I said, the food is great, the atmosphere is great, and every location is always top notch. However, with employees and attitudes like this, I will truly never return. This is a truly shameful way to treat the people who frequent this restaurant. As someone who travels 300+ days per year for work, I expect to be treated with respect in a restaurant . . . not the rudeness of someone who clearly doesn't understand that hospitality jobs require hospitality.

If_ZpoO87rlhT1S96TBgTA.text: It was a good meal and the tiger prawns wrapped in bacon were excellent. The steak and lamb were also good. Presentation was good and service friendly. In this location, you pay for that-£125 for 2 in our case for a three course meal. Bit expensive, but still good if you're OK with that.

ofih01HmLK0tf3BRuAKcgw.text: Best tex-mex I've had in London (well, best so far). Been back a few times and it's made it onto my list of favorites. To start, I love the salsas they bring to your table with chips to start. And it's real salsa!! Such a simple thing to start already makes me so happy -- I've seen some sad substitutes at other places like tabasco sauce of all things. Thankfully they do it right here.  The menu is filled with interesting combinations, but I like keeping things simple so I usually get chicken soft tacos or fajitas - both are good here. I like putting some of the homemade salsa they bring to the table with the chips on my tacos - Mmmm, delicioso.Also if you go, you absolutely must order the fresh made guacamole at your table to start. You just can't beat the fresh flavor when it's made at your table. I usually bounce back and forth between this place and Café Pacifico located close by. I prefer the food here at Cantina Laredo, but the bartenders at Pacifico are amazingly friendly and they have a wide selection of tequila - My Solution: Go to Pacifico bar for a drink and to Laredo for dinner and more drinks or vise versa :D

q5-Ev3yI0n4Uv85NldFKzQ.text: While wandering around Covent garden we happened upon this place. Suckers for Mexican food, we gave it a try because they had fish tacos on the menu.Sat outside to enjoy the warm October weather (strange!).  Really enjoyed the guacamole (table side prep was nice but not necessary, just happy it was fresh).  Unlimited chips, fan of the salsa options they had.Both my girlfriend and I ordered fish tacos.  Some of the fish in my tacos was overdone and rock solid, but the pieces cooked properly were excellent.  My girlfriend's were cooked perfectly.Also had the nachos laredo and nachos al carbon.  Well done!

K16JY51jAC3rpI_-YmBb5g.text: I don't usually associate 'gourmet' with 'Mexican' because Mexican food to me is homey, it is comfort food, it sticks to your ribs...  Cantina Laredo is located in a new development between Covent Garden and Leicester Square called St. Martin's Place.  They have outdoor seating, but they also have a surprisingly large amount of seating inside.  When we walked in, the host and the manager greeted us and the host asked if either of us would like the vegetarian menu.  That alone was pretty impressive to me, and while I would've like to look at it, let's be honest, I was going to have some meat.I usually opt for a bottle of Corona with my Mexican food...  it just seems to go well with it, but because of the atmosphere (and my date) we opted for a bottle of the house white wine.  Surprisingly, the wine was went very well with our meal.  Who knew?!  As I was having trouble deciding on what to have for dinner, I noticed behind us (literally right behind us... one sudden move and there could've been guac everywhere) one of the waitresses making fresh guacamole at the table.  Nice.  There were a lot of good dishes on the menu, and I will probably have to go back and try them all out, but I finally settled on the Chile Relleno.  My date opted for the Oaxaca Camarones Con Tocino... prawns wrapped with bacon.  The dishes are served with rice and sauteed vegetables, rather than rice and beans.  On one hand, no refried beans is a bit disappointing, but on the other hand, it was kind of nice to have something a lighter than refried beans.  I wanted to order some pico de gallo to have with our chips, but I didn't see it on the menu and didn't bother to ask.They brought us chips and two kinds of salsa, one was made with tomatillos and the other was a roasted red peper.  The tomatillo one comes warm, is a bit more tart, and is spicier than the roasted red pepper.  They were both nice, but I preferred the tomatillo salsa.  The chips came out warm and had just the right amount of salt on them!  Before our food came out, the table behind us had ordered a dessert... the Mexican Brownie, and they prepare this table side as well (again one sudden move and hot brownie and cold ice cream would've been everywhere).  Of course, we had made a mental note of this for later!Our food came out and it looked wonderful.  The sauteed veggies were corn with a little bit of carrots and zucchini.  The look of the rice made me skeptical that it would be flavorless, but it was pretty good, better than a lot of places, but could still use a bit of work.  The Chile Relleno was absolutely delicious.  I don't usually like raisins cooked, but they were a good addition to the dish, although I don't remember eating any almonds as the menu says.  And to those of you who are afraid of it because you think it will be spicy... its not.  The chile has a very mild, almost sweet flavor to it.  I did have a taste of the prawns and they were very nice as well...  I don't think I've ever had crispy bacon since I've been here in the UK, so the crisp bacon with the prawns was a nice surprise.  It came with some kind of sauce on the side, a green, tart, and spicy sauce.  I really liked it and kept dipping chips in it.Of course we decided we were going to check this brownie out (I have to go back and try the churros though).  The waitress brought a tray out with a hot iron plate, a plate with a chocolate brownie, vanilla ice cream (you can have it with cinnamon ice cream), and a small container of Mexican Brandy Butter.  She put the brownie on the hot iron plate, made a small place for the ice cream on top of the brownie, then she poured the brandy butter all around the plate causing it to sizzle and bubble up and making a wonderfully delicious smell.  The brownie was absolutely delicious...  it was moist, the center was warm, it was rich... delicious!  WARNING:  the brandy butter is delicious, but it is sticky and lava-like.  I say this because my date had the misfortune of dropping a bit of this on his arm (we had the plate between us sharing) and when he tried to wipe it off, it stuck to a small bit of hair on his arm... while continuing to burn him.  Let's just say he now knows what waxing feels like =(.The staff were very attentive and friendly and the atmosphere is great as well.  I will say that for a Mexican restaurant, I did find some of the dishes to be rather expensive... I mean I know it is supposed to be gourmet, but 13 quid for tamales... that's why it gets 4-stars instead of 5.  But still a great place for a date or a night out with friends.

NolJhX9CfK242BMgGd88yw.text: The guacamole is made table side.... too bad it was WAY too salty. But, at least the bacon wrapped prawn was pretty darn good.

WtfLmY9svcAYG_X1XG6_WA.text: There are few things more tantalising then watching your food being made right in front of you. Yet here I sit, tantalised at the scooping and swooping, squishing and mixing my guacamole as I sat drooling into my 2-for-1 margarita (on the ice, no salt, shaken not stirred). Fresher than one fresh prince from the 90's, the guac itself makes this place worth a peek.On the other side of my meal, beef and chicken tacos, with the beef being the agreed upon best. The beef was juicy and cooked with more love than a taco typically gets. Surprise made this good meal great.Though the bill didn't burn a whole in my wallet, I would mark this as dinner for a special occasion, and I would certainly head there when 2-1 margarita deal is on.  Otherwise, skip the margarita and head to the pub.And get a shot of tequila.

SBhPXcsHrJETAsS4LQkabw.text: Maybe I just had low expectations for a Mexican place in the middle of tourist central, but I was surprisingly impressed by this place! Think it was the modern but homely kinda vibe. The inside is all earthy tones, low-hanging lamps and bowls of bright yellow lemons - gives the place a nice warming glow to welcome you in on a rainy winter's eve :)6 of us slid into one of the wooden window booths, with the veggies of the group chuffed to get their own veg menus. I was more interested in the drinks menu at this point and stuck to my personal rule of thumb: if in doubt, get the strangest-sounding thing on the menu. 10 mins later and my tastebuds were being pleasantly confused by an Avocado Passion (in case you were wondering, that's an avocado and passionfruit margarita).The food was also pretty good, and that's from someone who doesn't often find Mexican food in London very interesting. Obv you have to get the fresh guacamole so they can dazzle you with the at-table prep right in front of you. Ok it's basically just a guy mushing a load of stuff together on a tray (and ours could've done with more onion) but still somehow made it taste fresher!Aside from that we went for lots of other things to share, including some veggie tasting platters of which the star was the stuffed jalapenos. Tacos also got a repeat round ordered, and surprise hit from the sides was the sweet potato bake. Obviously we had to get desserts too, and shared an ok apple pie, tried to be authentic with churros (though they were served with chilli chocolate which my tastebuds haven't quite come round to yet), and last but best - a chocolate brownie served sizzling on a hot skillet mmm....Solid choice that I'd revisit if I was in the area - ended up spending a little more than planned with all the re-ordering (oops) but left feeling full and happy!

-SSDoz_EMaSsyD2tFGwEPA.text: I should probably admit before I review this place, that Marc, my fiancée, is not keen on Mexican food (he says it all tastes the same, and is boring) so Cantina Laredo wasn't top of our list of places to try. However we came here with a huuuuge group for a friend's 30th birthday, and I was impressed with the way that they handled it.Good for Groups:- Our waitress was a complete star! She was friendly and helpful, and good and nudging people into making speedy decisions. - I liked that they made the guacamole in front of us...so it's nice and fresh- The set menu was pretty huge, and I like the way they brought out loooads of different starters and puddings for us all to share.Less good bits:- They were pretty slow to take orders/ bring food...but maybe that was just because there were so many of us?- They were not very flexible with big groups (they said if anyone didn't turn up, we'd have to pay for them anyway...which is a bit weird on a busy Saturday night)- It was quite expensive £32 for the set menu (which we had to order as we were a group) plus drinks were £9-£10 each.

tx-TnVHyYklkaQbSEOsvGg.text: The joy I experienced at first blush with Cantina Laredo is gone. Service is now comical; margaritas requested frozen were served on the rocks, specific tequila requests were mangled and when I explained wanted to redeem the "Free Top Shelf Guacamole" coupon I'd been sent by email it was met with skepticism about whether or not this could be used on a Saturday night.The chile con queso tasted as if double cream had been added to it (I love cream but in this instance it just made this normally bright and spicy dip taste flat and rather bland.)Unlike last time, the fajitas arrived sizzling solidifying them as my go to at Cantina Laredo. The purist's margarita was fairly faultless making it a drink I'd recommend. And the guacamole was as good as I remember it.Given that Hawksmoor, Dishoom and Bill's are all so close to Cantina Laredo in this area of Covent Garden, I'd be hard-pressed to choose this Tex-Mex import again unless they stepped up their game significantly.

UUZSTXNj6jxgTxBvlK1i0g.text: This place is clearly tourist heaven - while sitting in view of the door I saw at least four suitcases stowed away in a cupboard clearly used to that purpose. But don't let that put you off...good Mexican food is the draw and this place delivers.The guacamole made at the table is super gimmicky, but luckily was also delicious. I do recommend it. Can't give you a broad overview of the menu as my friend and I ate the same thing but I can say that everything we had was delicious.Chicken fajitas were lovely and the sides (particularly the cheesy potato thing) were especially delicious, if on the small side for the price. The wine was good and the desserts headed to tables around us looked fantastic - unfortunately we were too full to give them a try. The only downside was the price. At £19 the fajitas were on the pricey side and, as mentioned before, you didn't get a lot of your side for a £5+ price tag. Good food and nice service but, for Mexican, definitely not the best value. But then you are in the heart of theatre land and if you're a tourist you probably won't even notice.

U2azpy-sbMEniGdFjgRODw.text: I'd been to Cantina Laredo quite a few times in the past couple of years and had always loved it, but it had been a while since I've been and upon returning last night, I've got to say, it was a different experience.The service is lovely - very attentive and friendly, quick as well. And the food ts good, but not as spectacular as I had once remembered. I had the vera cruz enchiladas and my bf had the chicken fajitas. The portions have gotten smaller and now you have to order side dishes (including rice) for most dishes (i.e. the enchiladas) separately, makes for quite a pricey meal. For my drink, I had a watermelon margarita which was fantastic, perfect balance of sweet and sour. You can see why margaritas are their speciality.If I were in the area and looking for somewhere nice to eat, then I might stop by Cantina Laredo again, but wouldn't make any special plans to go there.

photos.caption: Photo of Cantina Laredo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Cantina Laredo - London, United Kingdom

z-XnOFdyJ10TR3BrQ54CUg.text: Good high end Mexican food. I think the food is quite solid here, well made with fresh ingredients. The service attentive. But you certainly pay a premium for the experience here. I recommend it if you want some Mexican and you're willing to spend a bit, but I'm sure you can better value for money in London (though perhaps not in this part of town).A decent meal for two with a couple drinks will pretty easily top 50 quid.

H9zd4CKs2YgEGrr_uylR4w.text: Very busy and loud, but great food and very friendly people. Great place to be!!! Also kids are welcome.

photos.caption: Photo of Cantina Laredo - London, United Kingdom

ojtaPp9vMEXTBgnMa-NlrA.text: I get the impression this place is frequented by theatre goers and tourists who otherwise don't know where else to go for Mexican. For the same price, there are a few other places off the top of my head where you can get tastier food and much better value. A few of those are actually walking distance from there!The restaurant was very busy and with no reservations, we waited about half an hour (not too bad!) There were no empty tables in sight and about 20 people waiting for a table at peak time. We were greeted with a smile at the door which made the wait bearable.Margaritas are £9 which can quick increase your bill so I suggest drink wisely if you don't want to spend a lot just on drink. The menu highlights their signature dishes in red and we found ourselves ordering exclusively those items. We declined their freshly made at table guacamole as fro £7-ish, we thought that was not such great value. Also good to note that mains do not come with sides. We enjoyed the food, but nothing really stood out. We spent just over £50 for 2 drinks, 2 mains, a starter and 3 sides keeping in mind the portions are quite small. We were full but didn't think it was great value. The staff were lovely however so the overall experience was favourable.

Jhc5zHmeUVfO75nLiq4htw.text: Service is distracted and super slow, have to ask for things many times. No gluten free desserts, Food was cold, enchiladas the size of tacos, shrimp extremely spicy--too hot to eat, chicken was sort of cooked, cheesecake was sort of warm and sour, and margarita came with sugar, not salt. Mexican food in UK is hard to find anyway, but this place does not make me a believer. Guacamole was pretty good. That's all I can say...

57xFv_TaSwigCzYjtVW_tQ.text: The guacamole was amazing. The rest was good but paled in comparison. The staff were nice. It was very overpriced, though. The seating was a bit awkward, our table was right next to the staff's station and it was uncomfortable with the staff looming on top of us for extended periods of time.

17QmU2TGVV2dQTHGnLFLCQ.text: I would normally be on the border of 3 stars, but I would return back here if I was in the mood for Mexican / Tex-Mex food so hence the 4 stars. The food is fine. The location is quite central when you are out and about.

EAkpxNHOdptfWyIRUKMU7Q.text: I had dinner at la Cantina last week, on the recommendation from a friend who took me there and we sat down for dinner early on a weekday. The staff was lovely, efficient and explaining everything in case we had any questions. Because it was early we could avail of the early bird menu: 20£ for 2 courses or 25£ for 3 courses. Reasonable value for money in that part of London. We shared a starter (aubergine based dish) and then my friend had the vegetable fajita while I had the steak tacos with creamy potatoes. We also ordered guacamole and our waiter prepared it from scratch in front of us. It was delicious, just like the rest of our food. Service remained attentive without being over the top. For dessert we both ordered churros. Or should I say, amazing pieces of paradise: tasty, fluffy, with that touch of cinnamon and a dark chocolate dip. The wine as usual is overpriced, however. All in all, a very enjoyable dinner experience. Booking advised.

621KlGsoelIjI0BYgKT1yA.text: We had no idea where to go for dinner for my friend's birthday last week, so we walked around Soho and decided that we'd try this place.  As someone that has eaten exceptionally good Mexican food (and Tex-Mex) here in the states, I was slightly tentative....We started with the guacamole and ordered adult beverages. The margaritas were very good (one person had strawberry and the other had traditional); I had a very interesting cocktail with avocado (can't remember the name) - but it was delicious! Very earthy and a little bit creamy...quite unique.For the main course, we had the fish tacos, pork tacos and chile rellenos. The fish tacos were grilled (not fried) - bonus - and absolutely delicious. The pork was very rich but also had great flavors. The report form my friend that ate the chile rellenos was positive - she enjoyed it (but it is fried - so be aware if you're fry-averse).We liked the food and experience so much that we went back with a group of 12 people a few days later - it was a great time and everyone raved about the food (and drinks!).  We sampled the ceviche and queso - yum!The service was friendly but a little bit slow at times...we had some trouble paying the bill during the first visit (we were on a time crunch as we had theater tickets).

309W1z_wX40bkijoO0TiQQ.text: Meh.£10 Margaritas. £6 tiny ceviche£10 for three (boring) tacos. Ok I was spoilt living in Chicago, but there has to be MUCH better Mexican restos in London

egkeO87gC1jd10u7gt9VDg.text: This rating is based on my lowered expectations of Mexican restaurants in the UK. Had we had this meal in Texas, I would have rated it a 2.5 (if there were half stars) and we probably would not return to the restaurant, simply because there are so many other better Mexican restaurants in Dallas.We walked into the restaurant, put our name on the list, and went to the bar. Within seconds, complimentary chips and salsa appeared and the salsa was good. I love it when restaurants have warm (temperature) salsa. After waiting about 10 minutes, we were taken to our table. The service was great, especially for England.We started off with chips and queso and table side guacamole. The queso was good but it was of a strange consistency. It was almost like vanilla pudding but slightly thinner. It tasted just fine, however, my husband could not get past the texture and consistency. Our British friend thought the queso was divine as he had never had it before. As for the guacamole, it was a bit chunkier than I like and having perfected my own guacamole recipe, I've become a guacamole snob. I debated smashing it up further but refrained. It would have been great had it had lime juice and a little more salt. No worries though - we devoured the bowl.For the main, I shared chicken and beef fajitas with the Brit and my husband ordered one set of chicken quesadillas and one set of been quesadillas. He said that they were somewhat disappointing - they needed more sour cream (they were dressed with a dollop of sour cream and guacamole on top of each quesadilla slice). I think that he was simply disappointed because he wanted sour cream chicken enchilladas and they didn't offer that. The fajitas were good, however, the beef was chewy and hard to bite. I will get them again, however, will go with chicken only. I ordered a side of cheese and that cost an additional 1.25. Overall, tasty.The dress code is casual, you can easily get away with jeans and nice top or sweater even though the space is modern and a bit more upscale. The British friend who dined with us stated that the place lacked character (I also read this on the Yelp reviews). I personally loved the clean and modern space. It was a nice change from the small crapped restaurants you typically find in London.Keep an eye out for the gratuity that is already included in your tab (12%, if I remember correctly).

nHgFCweuKQxuvwPiLOjVIQ.text: More like Can't-ina Laredon't. I feel like a huge joke has been played on me. There are a plethora of decent to good reviews from Americans stating that this place has the best Mexican in London. The only possible way this could be true is if a) they have only eaten at ONE Mexican restaurant in London, b) their idea of good Mexican food is average Mexican food from terrible American chain restaurants and/or food from Taco Bell or c) they've just really forgotten what good Mexican tastes like. After dining here I found out that this is actually one of those terrible American chain restaurants transplanted into London, so it's no surprise that I felt the way I did.We got there a bit early, so a few of us split the table guac and some of the tomatillo salsa. They were both actually tasty, but I'm not sure why the salsa needed to be served hot. The guac seems kind of expensive for about £8 considering you see what they put in it, and it's literally one avocado and a bit of chopped up onion, tomato, chilies and cilantro. I also opted to have a couple of margaritas, and neither of them wowed me. Fairly standard and average margaritas. But wait, the best of the bunch (which still isn't amazing) comes in at a whopping £12! For a fairly average margarita. So not worth the prices for the drinks.Knowing how easy it is to over-order at Mexican restaurants we opted to not get starters. Big mistake. For mains, I ordered the chicken mole enchiladas because I absolutely love mole sauce. I love it so much, I've hunted down good recipes and made it at home and kept it frozen for a rainy day. So when I see mole on the menu, I always get excited. My partner decided to get the steak wrapped around a shrimp stuffed pablano pepper. And we decided to share, because that's what we do. Then we ordered sides for the table, because SUPRISE! Unlike pretty much every other Mexican restaurant you will eat at, the sides are extra. Plus they come in at a value price of £4 per side! We split four for the table as there were five of us eating. The food comes. Now for £11 and no sides, I expected a pretty hefty serving of enchiladas. Nope. Don't expect that at all. I got two slightly larger than average enchiladas. Filled with bland, unseasoned shredded chicken (probably pre-cooked) covered in what turns out not to be a mole sauce but what can only be called a chocolate sauce. Now mole has a little bit of chocolate in it, but it's not a sweet, chocolately sauce. Where is the rich, development of flavors that Mexican cooking is known for? Clearly this chain has no idea what Mexican food is, yet somehow they're a massive American chain that has managed to set up a place in London. The beef was much better, but for £20 and no sides, it's like the owners are just laughing at you while they put your money in the bank. Basically it seems they want to make the meal look cheaper by having the mains include no sides. So if you want one small side with your main, you're looking at an increased price, but given the size, you may have to go for two which is going to put your meal up to a minimum of £20 most likely. For a plate of average Mexican food. Since we clearly didn't order enough food (because when does that happen at a Mexican restaurant? Here obviously), we all opted for dessert. I got the Mexican apple pie. So it comes out. It's presented nicely in a hot dish with a bubbling caramel sauce and ice cream. However, given this is the same dessert that is on the menu in the United States, it's definitely just shipped in and not made in house, and it definitely tasted like it as well. What a disappointment. If you do go here and get dessert, go for the ice cream. My partner had it, and that was actually a really nice trio of Mexican flavored ice creams: Tequila, Guava and Chocolate and Chili. For food like this, it's a solid 3 stars, if the prices were normal. However, they manage to make their mostly pre-cooked and pre-made food pretty and increase the price by making you pay extra for sides, chips and salsa. I really feel like the joke is on me with this place. They obviously know they've got a good thing going by their location, and their lack of caring really shows. Mexican should be about putting your heart and soul and love into your food, and here you just get sterile, nice-looking, bland food. Save your money and go someplace else. It's completely not worth the money you will spend here.

HUcwi3uPYZQXelQ3uq1v8A.text: This place gets an extra star for having Taco Tuesdays! Also, it has a veggie menu which always makes me feel special :)  I went two Tuesdays in a row and still feel like I would return next Tues ;) The decor and ambience is right up my alley and you can eat well for a good price if you pick well...The side of beans is a bargain at 75p and the drinks are fresh and flavourful. I really liked the stuffed jalapenos as they are home-made (which is sooo rare in London)... The veggie platter was decent - the cheese sauce made me want to give up giving up dairy - but hey ho!I will deffo return with the hubby and FYI - you get halfprice cocktails with your Yelp app! x

u91qXQavV430u2Hj848yfA.text: Upscale Mexican food in central London. Guacamole made at the table but it cold be more spicy and hold the green peppers.Salad was fantastic as were the carnitas tacos. Mexican brownie is the best desert.Full bar and outdoor seating available.

l2lkzYkRuAoEcOdiWKDHNg.text: Since I've been in London, which has been around 3 months, I have visited this place twice! This has become of my favorite Mexican food restaurants in London. I would give the rating a total of 5 starts, however, be cautious that while the food is of high quality so is the cost associated with eating here!In terms of atmosphere, I would suggest that you try and make a reservation ahead of time because in the evenings, especially weekends, this place has a history of getting busy.  Definitely recommend that you order the guacamole, which is made freshly at your table, and made to your liking. (i.e. ingredients, spice, etc.) I must stay that I've had just about everything on the menu and the only item I wasn't too fond of was the tamale plate. The tamale didn't taste have an authentic texture. Otherwise, the tacos, fajitas, stuffed jalapeños, etc were all good and highly recommend you try. The margaritas are some of the best I've had here in London and can pack a punch if you don't watch out! Highly recommend you try this place and even suggest having a group a friends join you as I did for my birthday!CheersLatino in London!

n4DaMFKeTJWthRjhUHeI0Q.text: Another Tequila Tuesday adventure, this time inspired by a recommendation and some positive buzz on Twitter. My co-fonuder and I wandered through the streets of Soho until we found Cantina Laredo, and were seated as soon as we walked in. My first reaction was that this was a very sterilized Mexican place... there are lots of places with a lot more character, a lot more ethnicity, and a lot more reasonable prices.Also, given that I think this is connected to a hotel, it's more of a family establishment than many places I go in London. It felt a bit weird, as usually our TT adventures can be rowdy and I catch up with my friend over a margarita or two.We shared both the chips and salsa and the guacamole (which was too salty!), and I had the tacos for dinner. The portion was really small for the price... having been to lots of places which offer the same thing, I think I paid about twice as much at Cantina Laredo as others. That's painful, especially when the rest of the experience isn't blowing my socks off.Nonetheless, Cantina Laredo isn't bad. The food is good and flavorful, just overpriced. They have a really nice location and the service is excellent. It's just that I've got a list of places with way more "Mexican" to them that I can enjoy for a lot less.

9bkwJc6tvz_Sd6SZrg-i_g.text: My girlfriend and I went here for dinner before a show. We both ordered the two course meal. Each of us got the crispy chicken tacos, the veggie enchiladas, and a side of esquites. Crispy chicken tacos were great. Small portion And a tiny bit spicy but great. Each of us got the veggie enchiladas. The enchiladas were tasty and very neat to eat (not messy). Our service was outstanding

photos.caption: Photo of Cantina Laredo - London, United Kingdom

FxblbJ6ZDN1blIS-fh0nVw.text: A few weeks back, I went to review Cantina Laredo, who pride themselves on being the heart and soul of Mexican food! There is so much variety to chose from and I wanted to get an authentic taste of Mexico.The first dish to try out is was what Cantina is known for- their guacamole! Cantina serves 8 great guacamole, which awakens the taste buds with traditional guacamole and unusual twists of the loved dish. The choices are; Guacamole Clásico, Guacamole con Chile Habanero, Guacamole de Chicharrón, Guacamole con Cangrejo, Guacamole con Chapulines, Guacamole de Piña, Guacamole de Poblano y Maiz.I was given the opportunity to make my own guacamole, which I enjoyed doing so. In the end, I and my friend made our own guacamole- Guacamole con Cangrejo. Which has Avocado, chipotle, red onion, jalapeño, jicama and coriander. Topped with white crab meat and citrus oil. Served with warm corn tortilla chips. However, if you're not daring with your taste buds then stick to the Guacamole Clásico which is made with Avocado, red onions, jalapeño, coriander, tomatoes and warm corn tortilla chips.Prepared at your table with a selection of salsa molcajetes and is both vegetarian and gluten-free. This is just a classic version of guacamole but is still big on flavour.We moved onto Entradas, which are small dishes to start with and are perfect for sharing. What I love about Cantina Laredo is that the dishes are suitable for different diets, whether you are vegetarian, or cannot eat certain dairy products like myself. My favourite Entradas dishes were the Camarones Rebozados, which are Tiger prawn tempura with chile and lime. The prawns are crunchy and full of flavour and are a great way to start your meal. Brochetas were brought, which are medium-sized dishes, which are also great for sharing. Cantina recommends two dishes per person to share. My favourite Brochetas to share are Mexican soy and chile de árbol. Slightly more spicer in taste, but the steak is tender and exuding in flavour.Tacos are also a highlight of Cantina as there is a variety of tacos for both meat and vegetarian lovers. My favourite tacos would have to be Tacos de Pork Belly which is Pork belly, corn tortillas, salsa verde with coriander and onion salsa. I am a big fan of pork belly and Cantina got it completely right! The pork belly is soft and salty, giving the meat a savoury taste. My final taco was something different, Tacos de Pato con Mole which is Duck with Nutella mole, corn tortillas and plums. The combination of the Nutella, plum and duck is quite unusual but seemed to work well together in taste. However, after a few bites, the Nutella was a bit overwhelming and sickly.For mains, Cantina serve PLATOS FUERTES, Which are larger dishes, designed to share or eat individually. These dishes are not served with sides, so you will have to add sides separately, which is a bit inconvenient, however, it does give you the choice to design your main, according to your taste. For myself, I chose the Rib Eye-con Mantequilla de Habanero Which is the 28 days aged ribeye (270g) with yellow habanero butter. I added Arroz Rojo which is Mexican red rice. The steak is well marinated but is very spicy, whilst the Arroz Rojo is very similar in taste to my native country (Nigeria) rice, which made me enjoy the rice even more. Throughout the night, there were many choices of drinks to try from. My favourite drink of the night as to be the Pine for Patrón, which is Pineapple infused Patrón Silver, ancho chile shrub and lime. The presentation of this cocktail alone is aesthetically pleasing, served in a short glass, with a thick cube and the cocktail in the small silver patron bottle, to be served over the large cube of ice. This cocktail is strong and is definitely a signature cocktail to try out! Price: ££(Although the cocktails are quite pricey)

Photo of Cantina Laredo - London, United Kingdom

lylSrcjYHjy5WIBAriEsQA.text: We had reservations and were promptly seated. After sitting for 20 minutes we left. Not a single waiter or wait staff ever said hello or even looked at us. Three young ladies that were hostesses were standing at the front by their desk. They were so engaged in a conversation that they didn't even say good bye or anything. Poor service. Too bad, so sad.

photos.caption: Photo of Cantina Laredo - London, United Kingdom. Menu for New Year's Eve 2017.
Photo of Cantina Laredo - London, United Kingdom

UpIkzNfhpoajvFPyMSZ_Zg.text: I came here during the 50% off relaunch period, so this review is based on significantly lower prices.The place has been really nicely done up and there is a great buzzy atmosphere. The service was very friendly throughout if a little slow in parts (massive wait between starters and main, although every table in the place was full so i get that they were really busy). We had the guacamole to start (there are SO many to choose from). I had mine with crab meat which delicious, full of flavour with loads of chunky veg. OH had the blue cheese one which he said was good.The mains came and at this point we were glad we'd overdone the guac, the 'large plates' in particular were smaller than expected at the price of a regular main. The butter prawns were delicious but a lot spicier than expected, the enchiladas disappointingly flavourless.The cocktails were the highlight with loads of interesting flavours to choose from and nicely presented. Overall an enjoyable evening, sadly don't think it quite lives up to the price tag so I won't be rushing back.

photos.caption: Photo of Cantina Laredo - London, United Kingdom. Mains
Photo of Cantina Laredo - London, United Kingdom. Guacamole

HY836ywSglvQm3kseXH6QA.text: Well my husband found this place in Yelp and I'm so glad that we came to Cantina Laredo. Love the food the desert,guacamole and the staff is so friendly. Totally recommend this place

photos.caption: Photo of Cantina Laredo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Cantina Laredo - London, United Kingdom

tne1Yy1CX5Hd07UEiopKgA.text: Had to downgrade my 1st review of a 4 down to a 2.  Food was not good: chips were stale and everything was bland. Won't be going back.

it-oFFlr5kkDbO_ynblTVQ.text: It is with great sadness that I'm updating my Cantina Lareda review to just 2 stars. They've changed their menu, and not for the better. Everything is smaller but more expensive. Frankly the portion size is laughable. This includes the table side guacamole, the shrimp skewers, and the Seabass. Honestly, I was just appalled at how little food you get. Not sure what happened to this once great restaurant, but after at least half a dozen visits we won't be returning-I can get better Mexican food at Chipotle!

IJEbKCDA3sObOPG2MplI9g.text: Definitely smells good, but okay food. The service is very poor. We had to ask for napkins, plates, spoons etc just for appetizers. The ambience is nice and it is comfortable inside, but they lack emotional intelligence and good service.

T5pCGmp-PQh2SVEttvQVog.text: Decent place for mexican...but there were no Mexicans or even spanish speaking people working there when I went

1WJoa-drFcxMaxeHl4F19A.text: Went here on Friday night for Cinco de Mayo, probably not the best time to go but we had reservations. They weren't ready to seat us when we arrived so went to the bar for a drink while we waited. After waiting 15 minutes, our order was finally taken. We had been served one drink by the time our table was ready, so I waited for the remaining drinks to take them over. Another 20 minutes later they finally had them ready! The guy behind the bar had no glasses to serve them in so the process took forever!Once at our table, it took another 20 or more minutes to get anyone to take out order, of which they only took half of for starters. After waiting over 30 minutes, probably longer, they finally brought out our tacos. By this point, they still had not come back to take our main orders. We finally put our mains in and got those another 30+ mins later! It was Friday night, but this place should be able to manage the tables they have in a timely matter!Besides the horrible service, the tacos were good, although overpriced. Wouldn't expect much less in this area. We ordered a few tacos, the shrimp ones were quite good and the shredded beef ones were a bit dry, I didn't get to try the others as they went quick with our famished crowd. Their rice was also notably good, but I'll just end on the chile relleno...if you are expecting traditional cheesy goodness, do not order this! This must be some odd healthy take on a chile relleno stuffed with a quinoa mixture and NO cheese at all! I wouldn't say it was bad, but not my taste nor what I was hoping for.Oh and one more thing...the watermelon margarita is not good, but I'd recommend the avocado passion fruit one!

2daF0dPDCFpGcITG_NNooA.text: Really good mexican food. Not tex mex either. The best dish had to be the guacamole which is made right on your table. All the dishes tested extremely fresh and whilst the food is quite expensive, it's definitely worth it.Interior was pleasant and clean and the staff very helpful in explaining all the dishes. The prawns wrapped in bacon were the standout dish for me.
